name: 1994canlii4796.txt

She also sought orders requiring Crown Life to comply with her request to transfer her contributions and restraining Crown Life from realizing on its security. HELD: Application dismissed. 1)The terms of the GRSP and the security agreement in this case did not offend s.146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act. 2)If the terms of the GRSP were breached by Crown Life, damages would be an adequate remedy. The Applicant's request for a restraining order was therefore refused. 3)Under the terms of the GRSP contract, Crown Life was not entitled to collapse the Plan. 4)No amount was due out of the Plan to the Applicant until she retired or made a proper request for a transfer. In this case her request for a transfer did not comply with the terms of the Plan. There was therefore nothing to which the security interest of Crown Life could attach until a proper request for a transfer was made or until the Applicant commenced her pension.

HELD: The application for a restraining order was denied. 1)The provisions of s.146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act do not apply to the applicant. 2)The loan agreement contains no provision enabling Crown Life to collapse the applicant's account in the Group Plan and thereby create an attachable pension refund. 3)The applicant has not retired and there appears to be no monetary sum current for Crown Life which could be set off unless a proper request for a transfer has been made by her. 4)The application for restraining order is denied. 5)The provision prohibiting the applicant from pledging her interest to the Group plan contravenes s. 146(2) and s.147(2). The loan agreement provides that upon an annuitant's coverage terminating, the applicant is to remain in place. Since Ms. Corscadden has not received a pension from Crown Life and there is no evidence of her having retired or of any retirement benefit arising as outlined in the Plan Contract and the reasons in Phenix apply. The applicant is entitled to a refund of any outstanding amounts owing under the loan agreement pursuant to s.7.1 of the PPSSA. 6)The loans agreement provides for the taking of security for loan on a Group Plan in two events. Cancellation of her employment is insufficient and the provisions of ss 146(12) and (13) are of no assistance in light of the provisions. If Crown Life is required to repay the amount owing under this loan agreement prior to its registration being revoked, Crown Life will assume the security interest of the applicant and the proceeds of the plan will be used to purchase a pension refund upon her retirement age. 7)There was no evidence that Crown Life had received a loan agreement in the amount of $3,000 from the applicant prior to her termination of employment for any reason.  8)Since the applicant had not retired, there was no prospect of Crown Life receiving any monies due under the Plan contract. 9)The applications for restraining orders were denied. 10)A restraining order denied.
